<denchmark-h:h2>VideoWriter fails quietly for non-square videos</denchmark-h>
<denchmark-code>In python, when using cv2.VideoWriter, if the dimensions of the video are not square, it will quietly fail and produce a 5.7 kb (for XVID/avi) empty video file.
When dimensions are square, the video is made correctly.
I tested this with several dimensions (1000, 1000), (720, 1024), (333, 333), (333, 334), (334, 333) in both isColor-True/False, and writing just pure black and white arrays of appropriate size. </denchmark-code>

comments.comment: Debian 8.5 FFmpeg 2.7.2 OpenCV 2.4.9 Python 2.7.8 Same issue. No solution in sight.

As said in the other bug tracker, VideoWriter will handle non-square videos fine, but width should be passed before height. The real bug looks to be in the error handling, I think this issue should be closed.

I believe I'm seeing this issue as well, but with a twist. I get successful videos for a time, then it suddenly spits out empty videos. OpenCV 2.4.9 Python 2.7.9 Debian 8.0 on a raspberry pi Essentially I'm doing the following: fourcc = cv2.cv.CV_FOURCC('M','J','P','G') h,w,c = self.frames[0].get('img').shape writer = cv2.VideoWriter( vidpath, fourcc, FPS, (w,h) ) for f in self.frames: img = f.get('img') writer.write(img) writer.release() writer = None self.frames is a list of VideoCapture'd frames. This works correctly for hours until it suddenly doesn't.

Here's a standalone script that illustrates the issue: <denchmark-code>#!/usr/bin/pyton
import cv2 import time import numpy import subprocess
fourcc = cv2.cv.CV_FOURCC(*'MJPG')
allret = 0 f = numpy.ones((480,640,3), numpy.uint8) h,w,c = f.shape print h,w,c counter = 0 while True: counter += 1 print "Iteration: ", counter time.sleep(0.1) writer = cv2.VideoWriter("test.avi", fourcc, 5, (w,h)) for i in xrange(20): writer.write(f) writer.release() writer = None ret = subprocess.call(["avprobe","test.avi"]) allret += ret print "FAILURES:", allret if allret > 5: break </denchmark-code>
After about 800 or so successful videos we then only get bad videos. Restarting the scripts starts the process over. This implies that something in the module itself goes awry over time.
